columns.text: In this problem, we will compare which machine is better based on their equivalent annual cost (EAC).

For the initial cash flow, we will simply use the initial investment. However, since this value is a cost, we will take its negative. 

For **Techron I**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cash flow}&=-\$245,000
\end{aligned}$$

For **Techron II**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cash flow}&=-\$420,000
\end{aligned}$$

For the present value cash flow, we will simply take the operating cash flow and multiply it to the annuity factor. Using an annuity factor table, the corresponding value for this will be $2.48685$.

To solve for the operating cash flow, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(-\text{Pre-tax operating cost}\times(1-\text{Tax rate})\\
&+(\text{Tax rate}\times\text{Depreciation})
\end{aligned}$$

For the depreciation, we will use the straight-line method which means that we will simply take the initial investment and divide it by the number of years. 

For **Techron I**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$245,000}{3}\\[15 pt]
&=\$81,666.67
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation of this machine is $\$81,666.67$

For **Techron II**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$420,000}{5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$84,000
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation of this machine is $\$84,000$

Now that we have the depreciation for both machines, we can solve for the present value cash flow using the formula in Step 5. 

For **Techron I**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(-\$63,000 \times 0.78)\\
&+(0.22\times \$81,666.67)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$31,173.33
\end{aligned}$$

Multiplying the operating cash flow to the annuity factor, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=-\$31,173.33 \times2.48685\\[15 pt]
&=-\$77,523.40
\end{aligned}$$

The present value cash flow for Techron I is $-\$77,523.40$

For **Techron II**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=(-\$35,000\times 0.78)\\
&+(0.22\times \$84,000)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$8,820
\end{aligned}$$

Multiplying the operating cash flow to the annuity factor, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=-\$8,820\times 2.48685\\[15 pt]
&=-\$21,934.02
\end{aligned}$$

The present value cash flow for Techron II is $-\$21,934.02$

Solving for the net present value (NPV) for Techron I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$245,000-\$77,523.40+\dfrac{\$63,000}{1.10^3}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$275,190.57
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value for **Techron I** is $-\$275,190.57$

Solving for the net present value (NPV) for Techron II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$420,000-\$21,934.02+\dfrac{\$63,000}{1.10^5}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$402,815.98
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value for **Techron II** is $-\$402,815.98$

Now that we have the NPV for both, we can now solve for the Equivalent Annual Cost (EAC)

For **Techron I**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAC}&=\dfrac{-\$275,190.57}{2.48685}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$110,658.29
\end{aligned}$$

The Equivalent Annual Cost for this is $-\$110,658.29$

For **Techron II**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAC}&=\dfrac{-\$402,815.98}{2.48685}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$161,978.40
\end{aligned}$$

The Equivalent Annual Cost for this is $-\$161,978.40$
Based on the computation, **Techron II** is the better choice since it has a lower Equivalent Annual Cost compared to the other one.
